question: What is the main purpose of a phishing attack?
options: To steal information or trick the victim into harmful actions
To test internet connection speed
To fix security issues on your device
To update your software
answer: To steal information or trick the victim into harmful actions

question: Which of the following is a common sign of a phishing email?
options: A perfectly spelled message from a trusted contact
An email sent from the official company address
Urgent language demanding immediate action
A personal message from someone you know

question: How can you check if a link is suspicious before clicking it?
options: Click it quickly to see where it goes
Hover your mouse over the link to preview the real URL
Reply to the sender to confirm
Copy the link and give it to a friend
answer: Hover your mouse over the link to preview the real URL

question: Which action is safest when you receive an unexpected attachment?
options: Open it immediately to see what it contains
Forward it to another person
Delete it or verify separately with the sender
Save it for later
answer: Delete it or verify separately with the sender

question: Which example best describes a look-alike domain used in phishing?
options: secure.company.com instead of company.com
support-company.com instead of anothercompany.com
paypa1.com instead of paypal.com
company.co instead of company.com

question: What is the safest reaction if you see an email from 'IT Support' but the actual sender address is from a free email service?
options: Reply and ask them to confirm their identity
Click the link to see if the website looks real
Ignore the email or report it as phishing
Forward it to coworkers so they are aware
answer: Ignore the email or report it as phishing

question: Which HR-related email is most likely to be a phishing attempt?
options: A monthly newsletter from HR with general updates
An email asking you to join a scheduled team-building event
An email asking you to urgently send your bank details to avoid salary delay
An email reminding you to submit your timesheet through the official HR portal
answer: An email asking you to urgently send your bank details to avoid salary delay

question: Why are unexpected attachments in emails dangerous, even if the message looks professional?
options: They can slow down your internet connection
They can be used to track how many times you open the email
They might contain malware or tools that give attackers control of your device
They are always harmless if the sender is polite
answer: They might contain malware or tools that give attackers control of your device

question: Which situation is an example of a multi-channel phishing attack?
options: You receive a single email with grammar mistakes
You receive an SMS and a phone call from the same number reminding you of a meeting
You receive an email, an SMS, and a phone call all pushing you to share an OTP for 'verification'
You receive a newsletter and a calendar invite from your manager
answer: You receive an email, an SMS, and a phone call all pushing you to share an OTP for 'verification'

question: What is a good security hygiene step when an email asks you to log in and update your details?
options: Use the link in the email to save time
Forward the email to another colleague to check
Delete the email without reading it
Open the official app or type the official website address yourself and check there
answer: Open the official app or type the official website address yourself and check there

question: What is spear phishing?
options: Random phishing messages sent to as many people as possible
Highly targeted phishing aimed at specific people or roles
Phishing that only uses SMS messages
A phishing test done by your own company
answer: Highly targeted phishing aimed at specific people or roles

question: Which scenario best describes Business Email Compromise (BEC)?
options: A fake social media message asking you to click a funny video
An attacker pretending to be a company executive requesting an urgent payment or change of bank details
A pop-up on a website asking you to accept cookies
A friend asking to borrow your phone charger
answer: An attacker pretending to be a company executive requesting an urgent payment or change of bank details

question: Which sign most strongly suggests a credential-harvesting page?
options: The page uses your company logo and colours
You reached the login page by clicking a link in an unexpected email
The page asks you to confirm your username
The page loads slowly at first
answer: You reached the login page by clicking a link in an unexpected email

question: What is the safest response if a vendor email suddenly changes bank account details for an invoice payment?
options: Pay to the new bank account immediately to avoid delay
Reply to the email and ask if it is real
Call the vendor using a phone number from your official records, not from the email
Forward the email to another department and wait
answer: Call the vendor using a phone number from your official records, not from the email

question: You clicked a link in a suspicious email and typed in your password. What is the best immediate action?
options: Do nothing and wait to see if anything happens
Close the browser and delete the email only
Change your password using the official website and notify IT/security
Unplug your computer from the power socket
answer: Change your password using the official website and notify IT/security

question: Which of the following is a common characteristic of a well-crafted spear phishing email?
options: It uses random names and generic content
It contains obvious spelling errors and broken images
It includes specific details about your role, projects, or recent activity
It is always sent from an anonymous email address
answer: It includes specific details about your role, projects, or recent activity
